Situation1: Be patient and understanding of each other's differences.
Expectation2: Maintain a safe and O39ean work environment.
Situation2: You notice a small, contained liquid spill in a walkway that needs to be O39eaned up immediately to prevent slips.
Story: I was on my lunch break at the construction site when my younger brother called, his voice tight with frustration. He was upset about something I’d said the night before, and I could hear the hurt in his words. I knew I needed to be patient, to listen and show him respect, even if we didn’t always see eye to eye. As I tried to focus on his feelings, I glanced up and noticed a small puddle of oil glistening on the walkway nearby. My supervisor had drilled it into us: any spill, no matter how minor, had to be cleaned up right away to keep everyone safe. I felt the pressure mounting—my brother needed me to be present and understanding, but my job demanded immediate action. My heart pounded as I weighed the risk of someone slipping against the risk of my brother feeling dismissed. I gripped the phone tighter, torn between the expectations of being a good brother and a responsible worker, caught in the middle of two worlds that suddenly felt impossibly far apart.
